[start of motion plan]
The task is to break the wrist while grasping the wrist.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms the presence of a robot arm equipped with a gripper. The task requires the robot to break the wrist while grasping it. This implies the robot must generate enough force/torque on the wrist to overcome its resistance.
The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world as such: The provided image displays the wrist frame axes in relation to the robot's end-effector. This frame allows us to translate the desired world motion into specific movements the robot's wrist should execute.
The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to motion into and out of the workspace camera view. Positive Z motion moves the gripper towards the monitor. Negative Z motion moves the gripper away from the monitor.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the object must move no distance to accomplish the task.
The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to motion to the right and left of the workspace camera view. Positive X motion moves the gripper to the right. Negative X motion moves the gripper to the left.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, the object must move no distance to accomplish the task.
The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to upward and downward motion in the workspace camera view. Positive Y motion moves the gripper upwards. Negative Y motion moves the gripper downwards.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, the object must move no distance to accomplish the task.
To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object must be moved primarily via rotation. Given the goal of breaking the wrist, a substantial torque around one or more axes will be required. Since there is not any constraint on which way to apply the torque, we will pick rotating the wrist counterclockwise in the Y-axis.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
To estimate the forces and torques required to accomplish break the wrist while grasping the wrist, we must consider the following:
- Object Properties: The robot wrist joint being manipulated is likely made of metal and plastic. The mass is probably around 0.5kg. The joint has inherent stiffness and damping characteristics.
- Environmental Factors: Gravity will play a minimal role here, as we are applying torque to the joint. Friction within the joint is a relevant factor.
- The relevant object is the robot wrist joint, constructed primarily of metal and plastic, has mass 0.5 kg and, with the robot gripper, has a static friction coefficient of 0.4.
- The surface of interaction is the robot wrist, which is connected to the arm, has a static friction coefficient of 0.4 with the object.
- Contact Types: Grasping, internal friction in the wrist joint.
- Motion Type: Rotational force about the Y-axis to break the wrist.
- Contact Considerations: The grasping force needs to be sufficient to hold the wrist. Additional forces along the X, Y, and Z axes might be required to stabilize the wrist during rotation and counteract any slippage.
- Motion along axes: the robot exerts rotational motion along the wrist's [rx, ry, rz] axes.
- Task duration: This is a quick, forceful movement that should happen within 1 second.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: Mass of the wrist joint (m = 0.5 kg), Estimated force to break the wrist (F_break). Assume the wrist has an estimated breaking torque capacity T_break = 50 Nm.
- Relevant equations: Torque = Force * Distance. In this case, we estimate the required torque directly.
- Relevant assumptions: The wrist joint is the weakest link and will break before any other part of the robot.
- Computations: Since we are estimating the torque needed to break the wrist joint directly, no detailed force calculation is needed. We assume a breaking torque of 50 Nm is required.
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 0.5 kg and static friction coefficient of 0.4 along the surface: To generate a torque of approximately 50 Nm about the Y-axis, the robot needs to overcome the static friction.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis: To complete the task and based upon estimation of task physical properties, the object in the image must exert no force along the X-axis with magnitude 0.0 N.
Linear Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon estimation of task physical properties, the object in the image must exert no force along the Y-axis with magnitude 0.0 N.
Linear Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon estimation of task physical properties, the object in the image must exert no force along the Z-axis with magnitude 0.0 N.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon estimation of task physical properties, the object in the image must exert no torque about the X-axis with magnitude 0.0 N-m.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon estimation of task physical properties, the object in the image must exert angular counterclockwise torque about the Y-axis with magnitude 50.0 N-m.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon estimation of task physical properties, the object in the image must exert no torque about the Z-axis with magnitude 0.0 N-m.
Grasping force: The estimated force range to ensure stable grasp is 50 to 100 N. Thus 50 to 100 N .

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "The robot wrist joint is primarily metal and plastic, with an estimated mass of 0.5kg and a static friction coefficient of 0.4."
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Apply a rapid counterclockwise torque around the Y-axis to break the wrist joint."
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of motion across the wrist axes [x, y ,z]. 
wrist_motion_vector = [0.0, 0.0, 0.0]
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 50.0, 0.0]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 75.0
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 1.0
```

[end of motion plan]

- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
